On the 1st of October, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, I was at the White Lion, at Paddington, with a friend; the prisoners came to us - they asked us to let them drink, and we gave them part of our ale; we went out, and they followed us, and with a deal of persuasion I went home with them, to No. 27, Nightingale-lane
, at a green-grocer's; we were all four in the room - I had three sovereigns and a half, and 5s. 6d. in my purse, in my right-hand breeches pocket - I staid there about half an hour; I was with Bryant - I then missed my money; I am certain it was safe when I entered the room, for I took the gold out in the room, wrapped it in paper, and put it into my fob; as I was in the bed I heard money jingling, and that was their putting halfpence into my purse, instead of my money - I got up, and accused them of robbing me; my breeches were at the head of the bed, the gold in the fob, and the silver in the purse - Bryant was at the foot of the bed; I accused her of stealing it - White was in the middle of the room; I jumped out of bed, and Bryant ran down stairs - she was not completely dressed; she left her gown in the room - White stood talking to three men on the stairs; Bryant returned - I turned up the bed and every thing, but could not find the money; I had not been to sleep - as I followed Bryant down White blew the candle out; I insisted on having a light - White sent Bryant for the steel, and a light was got; I gave them both in charge - one of the men said, "Who *** have you got there?" Bryant said, "Don't make such a noise;" we had all four been in bed - no money was found.

THOMAS KEY
. I am a groom at Hamilton-mews. I was with the prosecutor - we had three pints of ale; the prisoners came out with us - we went home with the prisoners; I heard the money chink - I had seen the prosecutor put the sovereigns into his fob - the money has not been found.

Bryant. While the prosecutor was gone for the Police, this man told me to run away. Witness. No, she said she should run away - I said, "It will be better for you - they are sure to find you;" she went out of the room.

EDWARD BALL
. I am a Policeman. I was sent for, and found the door fast - they would not open it; we forced it, searched the prisoners, and found only 4s. 6d.; the prosecutor was very doubtful about the prisoners.
NOT GUILTY .

2058.
CHARLOTTE WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of September , 1 pair of stays, value 1s., and 1 shift, value 1s., the goods of
Sarah Pett
; 1 sheet, value 18d., and 1 counterpane, value 18d., the goods of
Caroline Meddle
.

The
prosecutrix's did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 2.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2059.
EDWIN NORRIE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 15 shillings, the monies of
John Clements
, his master .

JOHN CLEMENTS. I am a broker , and live in Little Pulteney-street
- the prisoner was my errand-boy . On the 6th of September, about eight o'clock in the morning, I came down with 3l. worth of silver in my hand - I put it into a small box in the parlour, which was not locked, and in the evening I missed 15s.: the prisoner should only have been in that room at his meals, but he could have access to it - I said nothing to him on that day, but on the Thursday I charged him with it; he said he had taken it, and spent it at the theatre, with some boys - I found an opera-glass on him, which he said he had bought with part of the money.

THOMAS JOSEPH WEST
. I took the prisoner - he told me he took 15s., to go to the theatre with another boy.
Prisoner's Defence. My friends are respectable, and my master will bear witness to my general good character - it is my first offence, and I beg for mercy.
MR. CLEMENTS. I believe his friends are respectable - for himself I can say nothing.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2060.
GEORGE LUSH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of October
, 1 book, value 30s., the goods of
Charles Smith
, his master ; and
JAMES SMITH
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.

SAMUEL CHARLES SMITH
. I am a book-binder , and live in Cecil-street, Strand
. Lush has been in my service at various times, and was so on the 6th of October, when this book was taken from my premises; it is the Haldane edition of Aristophanes - I had seen it five or six weeks before - I had had it bound for a gentleman, and have had it by me five or six months; my name is stamped in it - I was sent for on the 6th of October, to Mr. Bohu's, and they desired me to go to a pawnbroker's, where I found the book; I have seen Smith before, but did not know him personally.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I suppose an ordinary person would not know the value of it? A. No, only scholars; there was a crest in it, which is torn out.

GEORGE LAW
. I am servant to a pawnbroker in St. Martin's-lane. Smith brought this book to our house on the 6th of October, about a quarter to one o'clock, to pawn - I asked if it was his own property; he said it was - I did not understand the language, and sent it to Mr. Bohn, to ask what it was; he sent word back that it was stolen - we detained him; he was stupified, and hardly knew what he was about.

WILLIAM CECIL
. On the 6th of October I went to the Cock and Bottle public-house, to take some refreshment; I saw this soldier, Cock croft, sitting on something, which was wrapped up in a horse-cloth; in a few minutes the prisoner Smith came in, not very sober, and said to the soldier, "Give me what you are sitting on;" the soldier said,"No, I shall deliver it into the person's hands who gave it me to take care of:" I did not take any particular notice till about ten minutes, when I saw both the prisoners looking at a book; I knew Lush, and said, "Will you let me look at it?" he held it to me, and I looked at it - he asked what it was worth; I said I did not know whether it was Latin or Hebrew - he said, "It is Greek;" Smith then said to Lush, "I will give you 1l. for it;" Lush said, "I shall not sell it, it is not my property - I got it so" (making a cross on the table) - I left them there with the book.
Cross-examined. Q. And this was openly in the public-house? A. Yes - there were a dozen more persons, who might all see it; Smith seemed tipsy.

TABES COCKCROFT
. Lush gave me the book in the public-house, and I sat upon it; he said, "Take care of it for a few minutes for me;" in about a quarter of an hour Smith came and owned it - I said I would not give it up to him; in a little time Lush came and had it - they went and sat down at the end of the room; I took no more notice of it - I saw them talking, but did not hear what they said; it was about twelve o'clock, just as I came off guard.
Cross-examined. Q. There was nothing to prevent any person seeing what they did? A. No - Smith was very much in liquor.
LUSH - GUILTY. Aged 26.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor, believing him to be in liquor .
Confined Three Months .

SMITH -
NOT GUILTY .

2061.
RICHARD CARTWRIGHT
and
VALENTINE GANLY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of October , 1 table, value 4l. , the goods of
William Edward Dolton
.

WILLIAM EDWARD DOLTON
. I am a cabinet-maker , and live on Saffron-hill
. On the 18th of October I received information that I had lost a table - I did not see it taken; I first thought the prisoner had taken it to the person I had it to repair for, and did not at that time take any steps to recover it - I found the prisoner Cartwright very drunk in a public-house in Cow-cross; he said he knew nothing of it - Ganly then came in, and said."Is it not all right? I took the table for Cartwright, and he sold it for 2l.;" I had them taken, and from Ganly's information I recovered the table, about six o'clock.
Cross-examined by MR. DOWLING. Q. You had been on good terms with Cartwright? A. Yes, and never suspected his honesty - I owed him about 2s. 6d.

RICHARD MILLER
. I am a constable, and took the prisoners into custody - I found on Cartwright 14s., which he acknowledged he had received for the table, and he said Ganly was innocent.

JOHN FORBES
. I saw Ganly with the table on his head between ten and eleven o'clock - I afterwards took him; he said he had been employed by Cartwright to carry it, and hoped he should get into no trouble.

JOHN RYALLS
. The prisoners brought the table to me, Cartwright sold it for 2l.; I had known Ganly five or six years, and I understood Cartwright was going into the same line as he was, hawking goods for sale; they came back, and purchased some goods to go and sell.

Cartwright's Defence. I had been drinking all night on Saturday, and again on Sunday, with Dolton; he was to pay me on the Monday morning - I went for it, and be put 1 1/4d. on the mantel-piece, and said, "There is that for you."

WILLIAM EDWARD DOLTON
. I had been drinking a little with him - he did not pay more than 6d. or 8d.; I went out about eight o'clock on Monday morning - I returned in twenty minutes, and the landlord said Cartwright had taken away a table.
NOT GUILTY .

2062.
JOHN BOWRIE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 2 saws, value 5s.; I stock, value 2s. 6d., and 1 bit, value 4d. , the goods of
William George Jones
.

WILLIAM GEORGE JONES
. I am a carpenter . On the 16th of October I lost my tools from the yard, in Coal Harbour-street, Hackney-road
; I left them when I went to dinner, and when I returned they were gone - the prisoner had come there about ten o'clock in the morning, and staid till I went to dinner, when he went half way with me - I then told him to go and get a pint of beer, and I would bring him some bread and cheese; I went about half-past twelve o'clock, and he was not there - I ran back to where I had been at work, and they were gone.

CEORGE DEAN
. I am a butcher. On the 16th of October I was sitting in the yard at which the prosecutor was at work - I saw the prisoner come and take something out, between twelve and one o'clock; I did not see what he took - he said he was going to help the carpenter put up the fence.
ROBERT DOWSON. These tools were pawned with me on the day in question, by the prisoner, between one and two o'clock.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I leave myself to the mercy of the Court.

GUILTY . Aged 53. -
Confined Six Months .

2063.
THOMAS HISSEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of October , 1 coat, value 30s.; 1 waistcoat, value 4s.; 1 shirt, value 3s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 4s., and 3 handkerchiefs, value 4s. , the property of
George Edser
.

GEORGE EDSER
. I am groom to Mr. Raine, of Uxbridge
, On Sunday, the 24th of October, I lost my clothes out of my box, in the hay-loft, over the stable; I had seen them safe on the Sunday fortnight - I have seen two handkerchiefs which are a part of what I lost; I know them by one side being run and the other hemmed; the other things have not been found.
Cross-examined by MR. J. ALLEY. Q. Then all you can speak to are the handkerchiefs? A. Yes; one of them has holes in the middle of it.

HANNAH CHEESEWRIGHT
. I made these handkerchiefs for the prosecutor about four months ago; I am sure of them.
Cross-examined. Q. Is there any mark? A. No; but I speak from the work - one side is hemmed, and one run in a loose manner; I swear it is my work.

WILLIAM FAIR
. I am a horse-patrol of Bow-street. I went in search of the prisoner at Harmondsworth, and left word with the headborough to send him to me; he brought him to me, with these handkerchiefs, on the 26th of October.

ROBERT TOMKINS
. I am the headborough. I took the prisoner yesterday week, between six and seven o'clock in the morning; my son said to me, "Here comes
Tom Hissey
;" I called to him as he had got by me, and said, "Young man I want you;" he set off running - my son pursued him about a mile, and then lost him; we went after him to Windsor fair, and in returning back we met him in Windsor Park - I said to him, "You are my prisoner;" he said, "Let me go, I will give you something;" I said, "No, I never did such a thing in my life, and I will not now;" he said to my son, "Take these handkerchiefs, and don't let the patrol see them."
Prisoner's Defence. The new handkerchief I bought of Mr. Holloway, at Uxbridge.
NOT GUILTY .

2064.
THOMAS HISSEY
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of October , 1 umbrella, value 5s. , the goods of
Matthew Newman
.

MATTHEW NEWMAN. I went to Hayes
, on a visit to my brother, on the 19th of October; I had an umbrella in my gig - I went to the gig at half-past eight o'clock in the evening, and the umbrella was gone; I had left it safe between three and four - I saw it again in possession of the prisoner, who was walking with it opposite my house; I let him go past about two hundred yards - I then ran to him, and said he had property which did not belong to him; he gave it me, and said he had picked it up - I am quite sure it is my umbrella, by two marks which appear as though they had been cut with a knife, and by a mark on the handle.

Cross-examined by MR. J. ALLEY. Q. Were you out with your gig the day before? A. Yes; I swear it was in the gig when I arrived at my brother's; when I was about to return it could not be found - I had cautioned my brother's young man not to take it out of the gig; I put the gig in the gig-house; I saw it in possession of the prisoner the next day, at six o'clock in the morning - he passed close by me; he saw me but did not know me - he got on about two hundred yards and I walked after him; I had been speaking to a neighbour when he went along.
JURY. Q. Did you see the marks you speak of in the umbrella as he went along? A. No; I knew it by its general appearance.

HENRY FRIEND
. I saw the prisoner about three or four hundred yards from Mr.
Charles Newman
's, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon; I think it was the 19th of October - he had nothing then.

THOMAS CLEMENTS
. I am servant to Mr.
Charles Newman
. The prosecutor came with the gig, between three and four o'clock, to see my master; I put the gig into the cart-house with the umbrella in it - when he was going to return, about half-past eight o'clock, the umbrella was gone - it was of this size and general appearance.
Prisoner's Defence. I found it on the road.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2065.
JOB TAYLOR BAILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
George Kearsley Davison
, from his person .

GEORGE KEARSLEY DAVISON. I am a printing-ink-maker . I was passing in Holborn on the 15th of October, about eleven o'clock, near Chancery-lane
, walking with my father, who is very lame; he was leaning on my arm- I felt my handkerchief taken from my pocket; I turned and saw the prisoner and another - I collared them; the other got away - the prisoner got from me; I caught him by the tail of his coat, and the tail of his coat came off - he crossed the way, and some gentleman caught him; this handkerchief was taken from behind his back- it is mine.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you see it taken from him? A. Yes; I do not think it possible for another person to have put it up his back.

Prisoner's Defence. There were three lads following the gentleman; I got before them and some person called Stop thief! - the gentleman seized another lad, but he got away; knowing I was innocent I went to clear myself, and tried to get the other - I never had the handkerchief.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 20.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Confined Three Months .

2066.
MARY CANTY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of October , 1 watch, value 3l.; 3 seals, value 15s., and 1 gold key, value 5s., the goods of
David Davies
, from his person .

DAVID DAVIES. On the 10th of October, between one and two o'clock at night, I met the prisoner in Hatton-garden; she forced me home with her - I was rather drunk; she took me down to No. 7, Lower West-street, Field-lane
; we both undressed to go to bed; I went to sleep - I had left my money and watch in my trousers, which I put on the chair - when I awoke the prisoner was gone and the watch; I cried that I was robbed in the house - they said I could not be robbed there as the door was locked; I lost a handkerchief out of my hat - I found the hat in the front room - I had given her 1s. 6d., and she was to stay all night.

ELIZABETH COX
. I keep the house. I let the bed to the prosecutor - I never saw the prisoner before; the prosecutor was not a bit drunk - he is mistaken in saying that he was; I let him the bed for 1s. 6d. - the girl was with him; they said they were husband and wife, and were benighted - she got up first, and then he got up and said he had lost his watch; I said he could not lose the woman, because I had got the key, but she had got into the yard - I stood at my door, and caught her going out of my neighbour's house; I said, "You have robbed the person you brought here as your husband" - she said she had not; I took her - she said, "If you will let me go, I will give you the watch."

JOHN LIMBRICK
. I took the prisoner, and have the watch and handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence I met the prosecutor at the corner of Hatton-garden, and took him to this house - when we got to the room, he said he had but 1s.; I was then going to put on my shawl and bonnet to leave him - he then said he would give me his watch; when I was gone to sleep he wanted to take it from me, and I would not let him, as he gave it me.
GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

2067.
MARIA BOOTH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 2 spoons, value 9s.; part of one gown, value 6d.; 1 pair of pockets, value 6d.; 5 half-crowns; 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence , the property of
Charles Culf
.

MARY CULF. I live in Brown's-court, and am the wife of
Charles Culf
. On the 29th of September I was in Seymour-place
, and met the prisoner, who had been a lodger of mine, but had left me about ten weeks - she said nothing to me, but ran and snatched my basket out of my hand; I was very much alarmed, and could not speak to her - she struck me, and I should have been down, but I caught a rail which supported me; she pulled me along very violently, broke the string of my pocket, and the pockets fell down - a young man said, "Have you lost your pockets?" I felt and said, "They are gone;" the prisoner had them in her hand - I went and said, "They are my pockets;" she said, "You d-d old fool, I know they are, but I will not give them to you" - when we got to the watch-house, the gentleman desired her to give them to me; there were a few little things in the basket, but in the pockets were the spoons and my money - she took up the pockets, and put them under her arm; she was in my debt.

HENRY CARTWRIGHT
. I was just coming home from work, and saw the prosecutrix and the prisoner - I stood a few minutes, and saw the prisoner pick up the pockets and try to conceal them to her breast; I went and asked the prosecutrix if she had lost her pockets - she said Yes; a Policeman came up and took her.
Prisoner. Q. Were you there when the Policeman came up? A. Yes - you had the pockets, and he took you; he is not here.

Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutrix has some things of mine - I met her in the street; there was another woman with me, and she said, "Did you ask Mrs. Culf to give up your things?" I said No - she said, "There can be no harm in asking her;" I pulled her gown, and said, "Do you mean to give up my things?" she said, "No, you good for nothing wretch, I will not" - she struck me twice; the Policeman came up while I had one hand on the basket; I let it go - she was walking off, and said, "I will give you a night's lodging in the watch-house" - I then felt something against my feet; I did not know what it was - I stooped and picked up the pair of pockets; I gave them into the Policeman's hand - he said, "There feels something like spoons in them;" whether she heard that or not I cannot tell, but she turned back, and said, "Give me the pockets" - he said, "I shall not deliver them to any one till I get to the watch-house;" when there she said I had insulted her in the street, and mentioned five half-crowns and two spoons, as being in the pockets - the inspector asked her if these were every thing in them; she said Yes, and was going away perfectly satisfied, and made no charge against me - he said, "You had better let the woman go about her business;" I went down, and then she made a second statement, said I seized her in a violent manner, and by some means untied her pocket.
MARY CULF. I have some goods of her's, but her husband begged me to keep them and the receipts, and he would come and settle with me.
NOT GUILTY .

2068.
THOMAS JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of October , 2 sheets, value 5s.; 1 counterpane, value 9s., and 1 shawl, value 1s. , the goods of
George Culpitt
.

JOSEPH COOPER. I am a constable. On the 26th of October, I was standing behind a brick clump, and saw the prisoner come by with a bundle on his head - I asked what that was, and I found it was wet linen; he said he was going to a brick clump for a pair of trousers - I took him; he was about three quarters of a mile from the prosecutor's - it was about a quarter before eight o'clock in the evening.

ANN CULPITT
. I am the wife of George Culpitt - we live in Copenhagen-street
. This property was hanging to dry at my house; here are two sheets, a counterpane, and a shawl - I hung them out at three o'clock in the afternoon, and missed them at seven; I never saw the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I was crossing by the back of the White Conduit-house - I picked up this bundle, and said I would take it to a Policeman, but I could not see one till I came to Liverpool-road, when I saw two Policemen going behind the clump with two girls; I went to get a pair of trousers, which had been given me by a lady, but they were not quite dry - I told the Policeman I found these things.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2069.
THOMAS SEATON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of September , 1 pair of trousers, value 5s. , the goods of
John Boards
.

JOHN BOARDS
. I am a pawnbroker . The prisoner was in the habit of pawning things almost every morning; I missed a great many things, and was at a loss to know where they went - one morning I missed a coat; I found these trousers at another pawnbroker's - I swear they had been stolen from my shop by somebody; they have my mark on them.

WILLIAM ESTILL
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of trousers, pawned by the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 77. -
Confined Two Years .

2070.
GEORGE SCUTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of September , 1 coat, value 10s. , the goods of
William Thirkell
.

MARY ROBINSON
. I live opposite the house of William Thirkell. On the morning of the 27th of September I was looking out at window; I saw the prisoner get in at the window, and get out something - I gave an alarm; my son pursued him, and my husband went and got the Policeman.

Prisoner. Q. How far is your window? A. Nearly opposite; I did not state it was one hundred yards from it- the window was partly open; I did not say I did not see your face; I am positive of your person.

THOMAS ROBINSON
. I am the son of the witness - she told me of this; I got up, and looked at the window - I saw the prisoner turn round, and pursued him a hundred yards or more - he was carrying this coat in a black bag; he gave it me out when I got up to him, but kept the bag himself.

Prisoner. Q. Did you come up to me? A. Yes; you were stopped near the corner of Redmans-row; it was you that gave me the coat, and you asked me to let you go and said you had nothing; I let you go, and you were taken again.

JOSEPH ALDRIDGE
. I am an officer. I was in Stepney-fields; the prisoner was delivering up the coat when I first came in sight of him - he then ran when he saw me; I called Stop thief! a man laid hold of him, but he was very active and got away - I called after him again, and my brother officer turned a corner and took him.

WILLIAM THIRKELL
. This is my coat, it laid in a chair in my front room - it was not in any bag.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2071.
JOHN SHIRLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of September , 1 necklace, value 2s., the goods of
Richard Robertson
, from the person of
Sarah Robertson
.

JOSIAH ROOME
. I am nine years of age. On the 28th of September I was at Mr. Hughes', the grocer, at the corner of Seabright-street
; I saw Sarah Robertson and another little girl with her -
Sarah Robertson
had a necklace on - she cried out, "Boy! beads!" and the prisoner took the necklace off her neck, threw it to another boy behind, and they ran different ways - I had seen the prisoner before - he wanted to take my marbles; I am sure he is the boy - I ran after him with the baby, and gave the alarm; I then went, and took home the baby.

FRANCES ROBERTSON. I am the wife of
Richard Robertson
; my little girl is two years old - she was at the door while I was in the shop; I heard the alarm, ran, and caught the prisoner - he had nothing then; he had ran perhaps, fifty yards - the necklace was worth perhaps 2s.
Prisoner. I sat down on a stone, and that woman came and took me.

GUILTY . Aged 11. -
Whipped, and delivered to a person who engaged to employ him .

2072.
EDWARD SANNAGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of October , 1 necklace, value 5s., the goods of
William Pinder
, from the person of
Caroline Pinder
.

JAMES DUNN. I was in Brownlow-street
on the 18th of October; there was a puppet-show - I saw a little girl , and heard a report that some beads were gone from her neck; I dived into the business, and took the prisoner and another into custody; while I had hold of the other, the prisoner stood by, and I saw the beads drop from his person - they had both been close behind the little girl; I found nothing on the other, and let him go - I was close to the prisoner, and am quite positive I saw the beads drop from him.

WILLIAM PINDER
. I am the father of Caroline Pinder. She came to me for a halfpenny to see the puppet-show - this necklace was then about her neck, tied with blue cotton and a common gilt snap - I had seen the prisoner before.
Prisoner's Defence. I never was guilty of any thing before, and I do not know what I am brought here for.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2073.
THOMAS ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of October , 1 hat, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Richard Osborn
.

RICHARD OSBORN
. I was at the Macclesfield Arms public-house
on the 22nd of October; I fell asleep, and when I awoke my hat was gone - the prisoner had been sitting a little distance from me; he returned, and I accused him of it - he denied it; Mr. Spring's young man said he saw a man with a hat on, which he thought was not his- and the next day the prisoner went and showed me where it was - this is the hat; I found it where the prisoner pointed it out.
Prisoner's Defence. He said if I would give him his hat he would liberate me, and say nothing about it.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2074.
CHARLES WILLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of October , 1 coat, value 12s. , the goods of
Charles Iliff
.

CHARLES ILIFF
. I am ostler to a gentleman in St. John's-wood-road
. I missed a coat out of his coach-house on the 24th of October, at seven o'clock in the evening - the door had been shut, but not latched; the prisoner had been living with my master for two years, but was discharged a week before - this is my coat.

THOMAS SMITH
. I am a pawnbroker. This coat was pawned with me by a woman, in the name of Ann Thomas - she is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

2075.
JOHN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 2 coats, value 25s., and 1 waistcoat, value 20s. , the goods of
John Griffith Morgan
and
Evan Morgan
.

DIANA MORGAN
. I am sister of Griffith and
Evan Mor gan
, who are in partnership as tailor
s, and live in Cleveland-street
. About seven o'clock in the evening of the 16th of October, I saw the prisoner in the shop, as I was coming out of an adjoining room - he had a bundle in his possession, and asked me for a person named Hanson, a tailor; before I had time to answer he went out with the bundle - I followed him, caught his coat, and gave an alarm; he dropped these clothes as my sister-in-law came to my assistance; he ran up the street, but was taken and brought back - here are two coats and a waistcoat.

MARY MORGAN
. I am the wife of Griffith Morgan. My sister followed the prisoner, and I went to her assistance; I saw him drop the bundle, and took it up - it contained these articles, which are the prosecutor's property; we have no person in our employ named Hanson.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined Six Months .

2076.
ALICE BYGRAVE
and
MARY PURSER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of October , 26 yards of ribbon, value 2s. , the goods of
Robert Bolton Shaw
.

SUSANNAH ELIZABETH SHAW
. I am the wife of
Robert Bolton Shaw
- he is a haberdasher , and lives in Kingsland-road
. Between four and half-past four o'clock, on the 27th of October, I saw the prisoners in the shop; my little boy served them with one yard of 1d. pink ribbon; they were in company together, and went away together - when they were gone, I missed some ribbon, and the Policeman brought them back with it in about an hour; I am sure neither of them bought it - this is it.

JOSEPH SHAW
. I served the prisoners; they came together - they asked for pink ribbon, and both looked at it; they bought one yard; I did not notice who took it or paid for it - my mother missed the twenty-six yards of ribbon; they had not paid me for it.

JOSEPH BURT
. I am a Police-officer. I found this ribbon on Bygrave; I saw them together in Sun-street: they went into two haberdashers' shops - this was about half-past four o'clock; I had heard of this robbery, and took them.(Property produced and sworn to.)
One witness gave Bygrave a good character.
BYGRAVE - GUILTY. Aged 13.
PURSER - GUILTY. Aged 17.

Judgment Respited
.

2077.
MARY DUFFEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of October , 2 frocks, value 1s.; 3 caps, value 9d.; 1 petticoat, value 6d.: 1 child's cloak, value 1s., and 3 handkerchiefs, value 1s., the goods of
George Bonsey
, her master .

SARAH BONSEY
. I am the wife of George Bonsey - we live in Gloucester-court, Spicer-street
. The prisoner was employed to carry loads for us in the market - I had been out on the 27th of October; a person came and said there was a piece of work in my house - I went home, and my mother was taking some of my property from the prisoner, all but two frocks, which I took from her.

SARAH CRAFT
. I was at my house, and one of my daughters came and said she saw the prisoner filling her pockets with the prosecutrix's things - I went, saw the prisoner, and took most of these things from her right-hand pocket; the prosecutrix then came, and found two more frocks.

BENJAMIN HANDLEY
. I took the prisoner, and found two frocks under her clothes.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. If I had a mind to steal I could have taken more things than that; I thought I would get a few halfpence, but it was my honest intention to bring them back.

GUILTY . Aged 56. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2078.
JOHN WILLIAMS
and
JOHN WOOD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , 3 sovereigns, and 2 gold rings, value 17s. , the property of
John Michael White
.

ISABELLA WHITE
. I am the wife of John Michael White - we live in the City-gardens
. On the 27th of April Williams came and brought this letter - he said he came from Mr. Horne, to borrow three sovereigns; I asked him if he would wait, as my husband was out - he was there three quarters of an hour, and I asked him a great many questions; at last, in consequence of the letter, and believing he came from Mr. Horne, I gave him the three sovereigns; I know nothing of Wood - this is the letter - he asked if there was any work to go back, and I gave him the two rings.

RICHARD GEORGE STATHAM
. I am a constable. I took the prisoners from the information of Mrs. Horne.(Letter read.)

MR. WHITE, You will excuse my sending you this note, but if you could oblige me with the loan of 3l. until Saturday next, as I have a bill come which I must settle this evening; if you can send it by bearer, I will call on Saturday and settle the same. THOMAS R. HORNE.

THOMAS ROBERT HORNE
. I never sent this letter or the boy , to get this money - Wood called to ask me where Mrs. White lived.

WILLIAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

WOOD -
NOT GUILTY .

2079.
ELIZABETH ROBINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of October , 3 shillings, the monies of
John Marshall
, from his person .

JOHN MARSHALL
. I am a sailor . I was in Ratcliff-highway
on the evening of the 28th of October - I was sober; the prisoner and another girl came and asked me to go home with them - I said No; they took hold of me. and the prisoner put her hand into my breeches pocket and went away; I put my hand down and missed my money, which was 3s. - I called out, and the prisoner was taken; I had not lost sight of her.
Prisoner. Q. Can you say I put my hand into your pocket? A. Yes.

SAMUEL DYER
. I am a Police-officer. I was on duty - the prosecutor called out, and the prisoner ran; I caught her - the prosecutor appeared sober, and charged her with robbing him of 3s.; two other girls came up, and I heard the money rattling from the prisoner to another - I caught her hand, and found there 4s. 4 1/2d.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw a crowd, and this man was calling the Police - there were three or four girls; I heard money chinking - the Policeman caught me, andsaid he thought I was the girl; he took the money out of another girl's hand - the prosecutor said he did not think I was the girl.
JOHN MARSHALL. I did not say so - I swear she is the girl: it was between eleven and twelve o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2080.
MARY ANN ROMNEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of October , 2 sheets, value 6s.; 1 blanket, value 2s.; 1 clock, value 10s.; 1 hat, value 2s., and 1 teaboard, value 1s. , the goods of
Joseph Trayling
.

The
prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

2081.
PHOEBE SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of October , 2 sovereigns, the monies of
John Barber
, from his person .

JOHN BARBER. I am a mariner . Last Wednesday night I met the prisoner - she accosted me, and I went home and slept with her; I had two sovereigns and some silver when I went with her, and I expected I had the same when I went out with her in the morning - the sovereigns had been wrapped in a bit of paper, and were in my trousers pocket, which I put on the chair by the bed side; I had slept in the night, and we both got up together in the morning - we went out, had a glass of liquor, and then parted; I soon felt a heavy drowsiness come over me - I then went back to her room, and when I got back I missed the two sovereigns out of the paper, and two shillings were put in instead of them; I do not know that I had missed any silver - I had given her some.

WILLIAM DIXON
(a blind youth). I know Phoebe Sullivan by her voice; she was nursing my mother - and a little after eight o'clock that evening she gave me two sovereigns to take care of for her.

WILLIAM MARLOW
. I am the officer. I took the prisoner on the Thursday morning, and found nothing on her; I took her to the station-house - I made her no promise or threat; but in going to the office she said she had a sovereign and a half at home, and half a sovereign she had spent abroad; she said it was the sailor's money - I went back, found this blind lad, and got the two sovereigns - when I went back she said she merely wanted to frighten him out of half a sovereign; she had not changed it.
Prisoner. My intention was to give them back to him; I never was here in my life.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years
The Number of Prisoners committed for Trial at the present Session, was 292.
Of whom were Acquitted or Discharged by Proclamation..... 91
Convicted..... 201
Of whom 18 have Received Sentence of Death.
8..... Transportation for Life.
119 carried up.
119 brought up.
71 have been Imprisoned for various terms, Whipped or Fined.
11 Judgments Respited.
